results.title: Children of the Peloponnese
results.creator_credit: Daniel Bertolino and Via le Monde
results.brief_description: Depicts the life style of families in the central Peloponnese region on Greece concentrating on the children. Shows the long, arduous walk they must take each day to go to school in another village, schooling, aspects of culture and sex roles.

results.title: Children of the mountains
results.creator_credit: Otto Ritter, Heinrich Fueter and Condor Films
results.brief_description: The children of the mountain-dwellers of Switzerland must learn to adapt themselves to the reality of their environment. They have their own task; the boys help their fathers, learning crafts for later life, the girls help their mothers inside the home, and trudging to the village on errands. Apart from school they enjoy skiing, playing a game like hockey, and riding on a sleigh.

results.title: Children of the high rise
results.brief_description: Examines the effects on children of high-rise living. Looks at how adequately their needs are catered for, and considers what the children themselves think of life high above the ground.

results.creator_credit: Clyde E. Elliott and Post Pictures Corporation

results.title: Children are people (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Lorna Ridgeway, Dan Douglas and Stockwell College of Education
results.brief_description: Shows a successful teaching experiment in primary schools in which classes are grouped vertically to include mixed ages, brothers and sisters. Explains how best children can be grouped and taught together so that they all enjoy school, learn effectively and develop their potential ability. Furthermore, it is claimed in the film that a more satisfactory social situation is created where social development is fostered to a greater degree than in single-age groups.

results.title: Children's thought and language
results.creator_credit: Michael Forlong Productions and Stefan Sargent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Looking at Research”.
The film outlines a project sponsored by the Social Science Research Council to study childhood development of intelligence and to discover how much children understand.

results.title: Children's Story Telling Caravan Bus
results.creator_credit: Hakuho Foundation for the Advancement of Children's Education
results.brief_description: One of the major activities of the Hakuho Foundation is the Children’s Storytelling Caravan Bus. The Caravan Bus travels to places where children gather, to provide a collection of books to children who are beginning to read. Co-operation exists among the caravan bus staff, made up of the storytellers, the rhythm game leaders, the artists who create the pictures and music and writers who provide the stories and rading matter. Special emphasis is also placed on travelling to those areas where the mothers do not recognise the importance of reading to children and thus not only providing enjoyment to the children but also influencing the mothers through these children. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Emperor's new clothes
results.creator_credit: Carole F Schwartz and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children’s classic story series”.
A live action film that tells the tale of an emperor who employs two tailors who make him a special robe. What he doesn’t know is that these two rogues are not tailors at all and when the emperor appears in public in his special new robe, no one can quite believe their eyes. Adapted from Hans Christian Andersen’s well-loved tale.
